<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 120, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 176, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 212, 425, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 212, 905, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|> 9702/33 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 359, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|> October/November 2022 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 230, 435]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 890, 605]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 220, 649]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 730, 682]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 720, 905, 850]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 382, 920, 400]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 733, 425, 751]]<|/det|>
P and Q are crocodile clips.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 763, 712, 782]]<|/det|>
The distance between the nail and Q is x, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 795, 640, 813]]<|/det|>
Adjust the position of Q until x is approximately 45 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Change \(x\) by adjusting the position of Q on the wire. Use six different values of \(x\). For each value of \(x\), measure \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 685, 139]]<|/det|>

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 672, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the extension of two springs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 180, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 133, 210, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 133, 584, 152]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[291, 165, 688, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 428, 532, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 459, 215, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 459, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
The length \(L_{1}\) of the spring combination is measured from the top coil of the top spring to the bottom coil of the bottom spring, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 505, 430, 523]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(L_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<form>\(L_{1} =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 599, 181, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 599, 821, 617]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(L_{1}\). Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 740, 920, 759]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = ................................................... %

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[896, 740, 920, 759]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 787, 180, 806]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 787, 228, 806]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 787, 578, 806]]<|/det|>
Add the slotted mass to the mass hanger.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 819, 223, 836]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 819, 621, 836]]<|/det|>
The new length of the spring combination is \(L_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 850, 430, 868]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(L_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 927, 918, 945]]<|/det|>
<form>\(L_{2} =\) ....................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 217, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 613, 90]]<|/det|>
The spring constant \(k\) is given by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 100, 554, 133]]<|/det|>
\[k = \frac{W}{(L_2 - L_1)}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 152, 400, 170]]<|/det|>
where \(W\) is 0.981 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 184, 333, 201]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 259, 917, 278]]<|/det|>
<form>k = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 291, 212, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 291, 767, 310]]<|/det|>
Remove the slotted mass and the mass hanger from the springs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 307, 920, 326]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 338, 180, 357]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 338, 841, 357]]<|/det|>
Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[88, 460, 121, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 460, 156, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 460, 205, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 460, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
Use the balance to measure and record the total mass \(M\) of the four **smaller** steel nuts.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 553, 917, 571]]<|/det|>
<form>M = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 586, 225, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 585, 680, 604]]<|/det|>
The volume \(V\) of the four nuts is given by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 613, 544, 647]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{M}{\rho_{\text{steel}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 664, 601, 685]]<|/det|>
where the density \(\rho_{\text{steel}}\) of steel is \(7.8 \text{g} \text{cm}^{-3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 698, 336, 715]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 790, 917, 808]]<|/det|>
<form>V = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 807, 920, 825]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 73, 181, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 72, 811, 92]]<|/det|>
● Set up the apparatus using the four **smaller** nuts as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 101, 700, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 388, 534, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 420, 220, 439]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 420, 571, 440]]<|/det|>
Bend the paper clip to hold the four nuts.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 451, 220, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 451, 593, 470]]<|/det|>
The length of the spring combination is \(L_{\text{air}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 482, 440, 501]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(L_{\text{air}}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[534, 528, 917, 549]]<|/det|>
\[L_{\mathrm{air}} = \mathrm{..............................................}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 560, 220, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 560, 920, 594]]<|/det|>
Gently lower the nuts into the oil until they are submerged but not touching the bottom of the beaker, as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 603, 670, 878]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 892, 534, 910]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 504, 91]]<|/det|>
The density \(\rho_{\mathrm{oil}}\) of the oil is related to Z by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 102, 536, 131]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{Z} = \frac{\rho_{\mathrm{oil}}g}{k}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 140, 344, 159]]<|/det|>
where \(g\) is \(9.81 \text{N} \text{kg}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 170, 735, 191]]<|/det|>
Use your second value of \(Z\) to determine \(\rho_{\mathrm{oil}}\). Give an appropriate unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[539, 312, 922, 333]]<|/det|>
<form>$\rho_{\mathrm{oil}} =$ .................................................... [1]
